workflow.name: Auto-generate social media posts from URLs with AI, Telegram & multi-platform posting
workflow.description:
## How it works

This workflow turns any URL sent to a Telegram bot into ready-to-publish social posts:
	1.	Trigger: Telegram message (checks if it contains a URL).
	2.	Fetch & parse: Downloads the page and extracts readable text + title.
	3.	AI writing: Generates platform-specific copy (Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn).
	4.	Image: Creates an AI image and stores it in Supabase Storage.
	5.	Publish: Posts to Facebook Pages, Instagram Business, LinkedIn.
	6.	Logging: Updates Google Sheets with post URLs and sends a Telegram confirmation (image + links).

## Setup
	1.	Telegram ‚Äì create a bot, connect via n8n Telegram credentials.
	2.	OpenAI / Gemini ‚Äì add API key in n8n Credentials and select it in the AI nodes.
	3.	Facebook/Instagram (Graph API) ‚Äì create a credential called facebookGraph with:
	‚Ä¢	accessToken (page-scoped or system user)
	‚Ä¢	pageId (for Facebook Page photos)
	‚Ä¢	igUserId (Instagram Business account ID)
	‚Ä¢	optional fbApiVersion (default v19.0)
	4.	LinkedIn ‚Äì connect with OAuth2 in the LinkedIn node (leave as credential).
	5.	Supabase ‚Äì credential supabase with url and apiKey. Ensure a bucket exists (default used in the Set node is social-media).
	6.	Google Sheets ‚Äì replace YOUR_GOOGLE_SHEET_ID and Sheet1. Grant your n8n Google OAuth2 access.

## Notes
	‚Ä¢	No API keys are stored in the template. Everything runs via n8n Credentials.
	‚Ä¢	You can change bucket name, image size/quality, and AI prompts in the respective nodes.
	‚Ä¢	The confirmation message on Telegram includes direct permalinks to the published posts.

## Required credentials
	‚Ä¢	Telegram Bot
	‚Ä¢	OpenAI (or Gemini)
	‚Ä¢	Facebook/Instagram Graph
	‚Ä¢	LinkedIn OAuth2
	‚Ä¢	Supabase (url + apiKey)
	‚Ä¢	Google Sheets OAuth2

## Inputs
	‚Ä¢	A Telegram message that contains a URL.

## Outputs
	‚Ä¢	Social posts published on Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn.
	‚Ä¢	Row appended/updated in Google Sheets with post URLs and image link.
	‚Ä¢	Telegram confirmation with the generated image + post links.

parameters.content:
# üì± Telegram URL Processor

This workflow receives URLs from Telegram and processes them into social media content:

- ‚úÖ Extracts URL from message
- üìä Saves to Google Sheets
- üìÑ Fetches content
- ü§ñ AI summarization
- üé® Image generation
- üì± Multi-platform posting
- ‚úÖ Returns post URLs

# ü§ñ AI Content Generation

This section handles:
- Content summarization
- Social media post creation
- Image description generation
- Platform-specific optimization

documentId.cachedResultName: n8n - Telegram Social Media Content Automation

parameters.content:
# üì± Social Media Publishing

Posts content to:
- Facebook Pages via Graph API
- Instagram Business via Graph API
- LinkedIn via REST API

values.content: =Based on the provided article content, create a Facebook post that is professional yet approachable, ranging from 100-200 words. The tone should be informative and engaging, with occasional light humor when appropriate to the topic. Focus on the key takeaway or most interesting insight from the article. Include a clear call-to-action that encourages meaningful discussion in the comments. The post should feel conversational and relatable while maintaining credibility. If the topic allows, incorporate a subtle touch of humor or a relatable analogy that your professional network would appreciate. Keep the language of the original text. End with a thoughtful question to spark engagement.:  {{ $('Extract Text Content').item.json.content }}

=Transform the article content into a punchy Instagram post of 50-80 words maximum. Use a casual, energetic tone with 2-3 relevant emojis strategically placed. Include wordplay, puns, or clever turns of phrase when they fit naturally. Focus on one compelling hook or surprising fact from the article. Write in short, impactful sentences that work well with Instagram's visual-first format. Include 3-5 relevant hashtags at the end. The post should feel fresh, scrollable, and shareable while still delivering value from the original content. Keep the languafe of the original:  {{ $('Extract Text Content').item.json.content }}
=Create an engaging, professional LinkedIn post (max 400 characters) based on this article:  {{ $('Extract Text Content').item.json.content }}

nodes.name: Append or update row in sheet

documentId.cachedResultName: n8n - Telegram Social Media Content Automation

parameters.content:
üîê Credentials
This template uses n8n Credentials.
- Facebook/Instagram: `facebookGraph`
- Supabase: `supabase`
- Google Sheets: OAuth2
- OpenAI/Gemini: API key
No API keys are stored inside the template.

üß™ Input assumption
Send a Telegram message with a single URL. The workflow extracts the URL and processes the article.

üñºÔ∏è Image handling
Generates an image with OpenAI and uploads it to Supabase Storage.
Set your bucket name in the Set node or via JSON.

üìä Sheet mapping
Update `YOUR_GOOGLE_SHEET_ID` and `Sheet1`.
Columns will be created automatically on first run.

# Final step 
Updates Google Sheets with post details and sends a Telegram message with image + direct post links as confirmation.

# Instagram & Facebook Site IDs

Remember to replace the palceholder with your respective site IDs

main.node: Append or update row in sheet

user.name: Karol Otrƒôba
user.bio: Automation & AI consultant helping businesses streamline operations with n8n, AI agents, and custom integrations. Founder of SmartCamp.AI.

data.details: The Function node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow. Unlike the Function Item node, this node does not operate on incoming node data per-item. Instead, you must iterate over multiple items of incoming data yourself. This can be useful if you're performing data transformation where you want to manipulate the number of items being outputted by the node (i.e. 1 item is inputted in with nested object, 10 items are outputted without any nested objects)

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
